title: Most RAG Systems in Production Are Garbage. Here Is Why.
excerpt: The real failure mode is not hallucination. It is retrieval confidence that nobody measures.

sections.heading: The mismatch nobody tracks
sections.body: Most teams monitor model latency and token costs but ignore retrieval quality drift. That is where trust collapses.

sections.heading: What fixed it for us
sections.body: We shipped evaluation gates with precision at k and route confidence, then blocked weak answers from reaching users.
sections.code:
const gate = score.retrieval >= 0.72 && score.answer >= 0.68;
if (!gate) return escalateToHuman();

sections.heading: The practical rule
sections.body: Do not push RAG to production until you can explain your retrieval failure rate by category and by data source.

title: I Fine-Tuned a Model and It Was Worse Than Prompting. Here Is What I Learned.
excerpt: Fine-tuning made outputs more confident and less correct. Better evals changed the outcome.

sections.heading: The expensive mistake
sections.body: We optimized for style consistency and ignored edge case recall. The model looked cleaner but broke on real traffic.

sections.heading: Recovery path
sections.body: We kept base prompting, added retrieval grounding, and introduced failure routing to smaller specialist prompts.

sections.heading: Takeaway
sections.body: Fine-tuning is a tool. It is not a strategy. Evaluation design is the strategy.

title: The AI Agent Hype Is Real But Everyone Is Building Them Wrong.
excerpt: Agents fail because teams design for happy paths and call it autonomy.

sections.heading: Autonomy without controls
sections.body: Most agent stacks skip explicit boundaries, so failure cascades look random and impossible to debug.

sections.heading: What changed reliability
sections.body: Structured planners, hard budget limits, and mandatory checkpoints before external side effects.

sections.heading: What to do next
sections.body: Treat agents like distributed systems. If you cannot reason about state transitions, do not ship.

title: The Death of the Junior Dev Is Exaggerated.
excerpt: Automation shifts entry-level work, but systems thinking and debugging are still high-value skills.

sections.heading: What changed
sections.body: Routine implementation is easier with AI tooling, but production readiness still needs human judgment.

sections.heading: What did not change
sections.body: The teams that move fastest still depend on engineers who can isolate failures and reason about tradeoffs.

sections.heading: Practical advice
sections.body: Build in public, ship small systems weekly, and write what you learn. That compounds quickly.

title: Switching from PyTorch to JAX: A Retrospective.
excerpt: JAX improved a narrow part of the stack, but migration cost was real and easy to underestimate.

sections.heading: Why we switched
sections.body: We needed better control over compilation and throughput for repeat batch workloads.

sections.heading: Unexpected friction
sections.body: Library compatibility and team familiarity slowed delivery more than benchmark docs suggested.

sections.heading: What I would repeat
sections.body: Pilot migration on a single service first, prove value, then scale if operational complexity stays bounded.
